“Windy Hill Farm and Preserve is a place where guests can come to unwind and recharge and leave with a renewed connection to the world around them – and the experience engages all the senses,” General Manager Steven Brewington said. “Adding Cruz’s music against the backdrop of the farm was a wonderful way for us to celebrate our opening. Now, with his help, we’ll spend the summer adding the sounds of the region amid the visual beauty of nature, the tastes of the restaurant, the smell of fresh air.

“We can’t wait for people to visit us and experience Windy Hill – whether as overnight guests or coming to enjoy a concert.”

The Summer Concert Series at Windy Hill Farm and Preserve will feature the following artists:

Cruz Contreras

Amanda Anne Platt & The Honeycutters

Tyler Ramsey and Carl Broemel

Jill Andrews

Caroline Spence

Erick Baker

Chatham County Line

The Steel Wheels

Additional artists to be announced

In addition to VIP concert access included for overnight guests at the all-inclusive resort, tickets are available to the public and include options for the Saturday night outdoor concert with either dining at Wilder restaurant before the show or inventive takes on classic concert concessions during the show. Each concert also will have a cash bar.

Tickets range without overnight accommodations from $50-$150. Tickets for the first three shows currently are on sale and include Cruz Contreras on Friday, July 1, and Saturday, July 2; Amanda Anne Platt & The Honeycutters on Saturday, July 16; and Tyler Ramsey and Carl Broemel on Saturday, July 30.

Additional artists announcements and a full schedule of the concert series from July-October 2022 will be posted at windyhillfarmtn.com/music, where the public also can purchase tickets.

“Music tells the story of a place: its history, its people, its tradition,” Brewington said. “The way we aim to preserve and celebrate East Tennessee heritage at Windy Hill Farm will be amplified by these artists, and we look forward to enjoying the music and the farm together.”

For more information visit windyhillfarmtn.com or call 865-657-1700.

Tennova Healthcare - North Knoxville Medical Center uses new technology to enhance maternal and fetal safety

Knoxville, TN (June 22, 2022) – The childbirth team at Tennova Healthcare-North Knoxville Medical Center is now using an artificial intelligence-based maternal-fetal early warning system called PeriWatch Vigilance to enhance patient safety during labor and delivery. The system continuously monitors maternal vital signs, fetal heart rate, contractions, and labor progression to help clinicians quickly identify any concerning developments for faster intervention.

Tennova Healthcare-North Knoxville Medical Center delivers more than 750 babies each year. Stacy Wood, RN, director of women’s services, indicates this new technology is an important resource to support maternal/fetal health and safe deliveries.

“Every delivery is unique and the health and well-being of every mom and baby is our priority during childbirth,” says Jeanette Toney, MD. “While most births happen without complication, there are some inherent risks in the delivery of a newborn. This new technology adds another layer of protection throughout the labor process to help our maternity team recognize, prevent and respond to avoidable complications.”

Through pattern recognition, the technology can also pinpoint opportunities for overall improvement based on consolidated data from multiple births. As the maternity team reviews trends and identifies areas where improvement is possible, the hospital can use that information to develop protocols that further increase safety and may lead to better outcomes for mothers and babies.

“By investing in this technology, Tennova Healthcare-North Knoxville Medical Center is making labor and delivery safer for mothers and babies,” said Colin McRae, chief executive officer, Tennova Healthcare-North Knoxville Medical Center. “Our physicians and nurses are highly skilled medical professionals and excellent caregivers and they appreciate the use of technology to support their work, especially when it helps keep our patients safe.”

The team at Tennova Healthcare-North Knoxville Medical Center has received the Daisy Team award for exceptional prenatal, delivery and postpartum care. Additionally, the spacious birthing suites at Tennova Healthcare-North Knoxville Medical Center feature a labor, delivery, recovery and postpartum (LDRP) model that keeps mother and child together from admission to discharge. The larger rooms also accommodate larger family support networks.

To learn more about Tennova Healthcare-North Knoxville Medical Center childbirth services or to find a physician, visit tennovanorthknoxville.com/maternity-care-services or call 865-859-8000.

Tennova Healthcare-North Knoxville Medical Center offers a free e-newsletter with a monthly dose of health and wellness inspiration sent directly to your inbox from a trusted medical source. Go to tennovanorthknoxville.com/enewsletter-sign-up for sign-up page on hospital website.

UTHSC team receives $2.19 million to study neurotoxicity of commonly-used chemical solvent

Memphis, Tenn. (June 20, 2022) – A team of University of Tennessee Health Science Center researchers has been awarded $2.19 million from the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences for their investigation of the neurotoxic effects of toluene, a common chemical found in many household products.

Alex M. Dopico, MD, Van Vleet Chair of Excellence and professor in the Department of Pharmacology, Addiction Science, and Toxicology (PHAST) in the UTHSC College of Medicine, and Anna N. Bukiya, PhD, professor in the same department, are principal investigators on the award. Jeff Steketee, PhD, also professor in the PHAST Department and chair of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee, is a co-investigator.

Toluene reaches the brain through inhalation. Intoxication with toluene, whether accidental or following recreational use (e.g., “glue sniffing”), leads to dizziness, blurred vision and even neurological deficits with catastrophic outcomes, including death. A reduction in blood flow to the brain is thought to contribute to these toxic effects, but how and why toluene exposure affects the brain circulation is not known.

The team hypothesizes that toluene reduces the activity of a protein (the BK channel) located in the cerebral artery muscle cells, causing the brain arteries to constrict upon exposure. Performing tests at the molecular level using computational methods, and in vitro and in vivo evaluation of BK channel function in animal models, the team aims to identify the specific mechanism and site of action in BK channels that makes cerebral arteries constrict in the presence of toluene. Their tests will include delivering new selective drug therapies for early intervention in toluene-induced brain ischemia.

The project, titled “Ionic mechanisms of toluene cerebrovascular actions,” is being funded over five years.

As Tennessee’s only public, statewide, academic health system, the mission of the University of Tennessee Health Science Center is to bring the benefits of the health sciences to the achievement and maintenance of human health through education, research, clinical care, and public service, with a focus on the citizens of Tennessee and the region. The main campus in Memphis includes six colleges: Dentistry, Graduate Health Sciences, Health Professions, Medicine, Nursing and Pharmacy. UTHSC also educates and trains medicine, pharmacy, and/or health professions students, as well as medical residents and fellows, at major sites in Knoxville, Chattanooga and Nashville. For more information, visit www.uthsc.edu. Find us on Facebook: facebook.com/uthsc, on Twitter: twitter.com/uthsc and on Instagram: instagram.com/uthsc.

Pilot Flying J introduces exclusive new women’s clothing line by Buffalo Outdoors

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. (June 21, 2022) – From work wear to casual wear, Pilot Flying J’s exclusive clothing line by Buffalo Outdoors is designed with every guest in mind and is now available at more than 200 participating Pilot and Flying J travel centers across North America. New to the collection is an exclusive line of women’s clothing, available at select stores, that features travel ready attire including tie-dye bucket hats, jogger and pullover sets, tank tops, graphic tees and more.

“We looked at current clothing trends and what our guests would want to see in our clothing pieces,” said Theresa Rosas, manager of General Merchandise for Pilot Company. “Our goal is to provide functionality and comfort, and we’ve worked with Buffalo Outdoors to curate these items specifically for our guests in this season’s latest styles.”

The latest release of Buffalo Outdoors men’s and women’s clothes for Pilot Flying J provides travelers to professional drivers with more options for high quality and trendy products while on the road. In addition to everyday casual pieces like lightweight button downs, hoodies, shorts, and accessories, Pilot Flying J offers functional apparel and safety gear, such as hardhats, gloves, and reflective jackets that are made tough for truck drivers and other hard-working professionals.

“Whether you’re on the road for work or fun and find yourself needing a fresh outfit, we’ve got you covered from head to toe,” said Rosas. “Swing by Pilot Flying J for a convenient way to shop on-the-go from a variety of brands and products.”

Pilot Flying J and Buffalo Outdoors will continue to explore new seasonal styles and plan for extending this exclusive clothing line to more travel center locations later this year with the release of a fall and winter collection.

Currents: Recent Art from East Tennessee and Beyond, pays tribute to contemporary women artists represented in the collection of the KMA

This exhibition, a special edition of the KMA’s permanent installation Currents: Recent Art from East Tennessee and Beyond, pays tribute to contemporary women artists represented in the collection of the Knoxville Museum of Art. This show and Women Artists: Highlights from the Hunter Museum of American Art (one floor up) document what two important Tennessee cultural organizations are doing to support and empower women artists.

Like the Hunter, the KMA has actively sought to acquire outstanding works by women, who have long lagged behind their male counterparts when it comes to museum-level recognition. The selection on view reflects the broad technical and aesthetic range found in contemporary art by women. A mixed media painting on wooden sections by Alison Moritsugu conveys a monumental landscape, expansive yet incomplete. Nancy Rubins elevates graphite drawing into a large sculptural construction apparently shaped by violent forces. British artist Marilène Oliver constructs provocative portraits of her family in the form of acrylic sheets imprinted with digital medical scans. Patty Chang uses water and mirrors to transform her own image taken in a Belgian church into a complex photographic work fragmented by harsh angles and provocative reflections. In her video Joan of Arc, Alex McQuilkin responds to Maria Falconetti’s memorable lead role in the legendary 1928 French silent film by Carl Dreyer, and to the film’s themes of adolescent desire, faith, and suffering. These and other selected works call overdue attention to women’s significant role in reshaping the contemporary art landscape.

The artists featured in this exhibition are Patty Chang, Janet Fish, Marcia Goldenstein, Michelle Grabner, EJ Hauser, Julie Heffernan, Jean Hess, Kate Katomski, Karen LaMonte, Pam Longobardi, Lauren Luloff, Alex McQuilkin, Alison Mortisugu, Althea Murphy-Price, Marilène Oliver, Amy Pleasant, Sumi Putman, Nancy Rubins, Tommie Rush, Denise Stewart-Sanabria, Jemima Stehli, and Toots Zynsky.

Knoxville, Tenn. – MEDIC is teaming up with the United Way of Greater Knoxville to collaborate with local nonprofits through August 31 to promote blood donation, stabilize the blood product inventory, and provide mini-grants for the assistance.

Ripken Baseball expands programming in Pigeon Forge

PIGEON FORGE, Tennessee (May 24, 2022) – Ripken Baseball, the leader in youth sports events, announced they are gaining access to four additional fields in the City of Pigeon Forge. As one of the most sought-after youth sports complexes in the country, Ripken Experience™ Pigeon Forge will be able to host teams from around the country on 10 total fields, including access to the newly renovated fields at Pigeon Forge’s Wear Farm City Park.

The park’s four fields will be completely upgraded and reimagined prior to the start of the 2023 season. Similar to the original six fields at Ripken Experience™ Pigeon Forge which opened in 2016, each field at Wear Farm City Park will become a youth replica of famous Major League Baseball parks of the past and present.

Residents of Pigeon Forge will benefit from the renovations as Wear Farm City Park will continue to host tournaments throughout the year on state-of-the-art artificial turf that closely replicates real grass.

“Every year, our teams and their families take home countless fond memories of the Pigeon Forge area when they participate in The Ripken Experience™,” said Cal Ripken, Jr., who co-founded Ripken Baseball with his brother Bill Ripken. “The views are unbelievable and the feeling you have when you experience our complex is special. The demand to play here is through the roof. This is an exciting opportunity to expand and welcome even more baseball families to Pigeon Forge.”

Wear Farm City Park’s four fields will be transformed into youth replicas of the following big league stadiums: St. Louis’ Busch Stadium, Pittsburgh’s Three Rivers Stadium, Philadelphia’s Veterans Stadium, and Cincinnati’s Riverfront Stadium. The $3 million renovation project will begin this summer.

“Pigeon Forge’s partnership with Ripken Baseball is a successful one, as demonstrated by the annual increase in demand for the ball fields and the direct impact on our city’s tourism industry due to the many families who visit,” said Pigeon Forge City Manager Earlene Teaster. “The upgrades to Wear Farm City Park are a win-win for The Ripken Experience™ and our Pigeon Forge residents as these fields bring vast improvements for everyone to enjoy.”

Pigeon Forge residents and local youth teams will enjoy the renovations immediately following completion. The Ripken Experience™ Pigeon Forge’s access to Wear Farm City Park applies primarily to daytime hours during the summer season, allowing the four baseball fields to remain available for Pigeon Forge residents during evenings, weekends, and most Fridays. The addition of artificial turf provides longer days during the winter months (November through early March), earlier year-round start times, and quicker turnaround during the event of rain. Wear Farm City Park is open daily from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. The park, which also has soccer and youth football facilities, will continue to host youth baseball leagues.

The Ripken Experience™ Pigeon Forge hosts more than 1,000 teams annually from over 30 states, traveling from as far away as California, Alaska, and overseas. Players’ families, many of whom are first-time visitors to Pigeon Forge, have a significant impact on the Pigeon Forge economy. A 2018 economic impact study attributed $33.8 million in visitor spending to The Ripken Experience™ Pigeon Forge during the facility’s nine-month season that year.

The appeal of Pigeon Forge as a family vacation destination was a major reason the city built the $22.5 million complex and contracted with Ripken Baseball to operate it. During seven seasons of operations, the facility has solidified Pigeon Forge as a major sports tourism destination. In addition, research indicates that 99 percent of those who visit the facility reside outside of Sevier County.

Tournament participants, coaches, and their families contribute to the local economy through overnight lodging stays ticket purchases to area attractions, restaurant dining, and other purchases.

Pigeon Forge is located in Sevier County just six miles from the entrance to Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

Since opening its doors in March 2016, more than 5,000 youth baseball teams and 250 high school softball teams have taken to the six fields at The Ripken Experience Pigeon Forge. In total, more than 75,000 players and coaches have traveled to play ball on fields that offer unobstructed views of the Great Smoky Mountains, with an additional 1,000 teams expected to travel to the complex for competition in 2022.

The Ripken Experience™ Pigeon Forge is located on a ridge above Pigeon Forge. Each field borrows its design inspiration from current and former ballparks highlighting the professional player progression from the Minor to Major Leagues, including Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore.

The others are Calfee Park in Pulaski, Va., the oldest park in the Appalachian League; Fluor Field in Greenville, S.C., known as “Little Fenway”; Engel Stadium in Chattanooga, Tenn., a filming location for the “42” movie about Jackie Robinson; BB&T Ballpark in Winston-Salem, N.C.; and Isotopes Park in Albuquerque, N.M.

The Ripken Experience™ Pigeon Forge hosts tournaments nine months out of the year and offers year-round branded events in its 14,000-square-foot clubhouse. Tournaments are free to spectators, and parking is free at the complex.

Visitor information about Pigeon Forge is available online at MyPigeonForge.com and toll-free at 800-251-9100. To learn more about Ripken Baseball and for The Ripken Experience™ Pigeon Forge, visit RipkenBaseball.com.

search_result.title: Plenty of Notre Dame men's basketball topics to discuss in the ...
search_result.text:
Thomas Noie: How about some hoops? Yeah, it's the middle of July. yeah, Notre Dame football starts preseason camp in six days. But it's always a good time to circle back around to the Notre Dame men's basketball program, where the Micah Shrewsberry Era is live. Area media got a sneak peek at the program this week, and we're here to talk everything Irish hoops. To leave a question or comment, make sure you include your name and hometown. With that, you know the drill ... let's light this chat candle.

Mark from Rochester: Tom, thanks for doing this as always. How will the style of play change with Micah at the helm? Curious on the big differences if some are known at this point. Thanks!Thomas Noie: Mark: We're all curious about that. Notre Dame was it was the last few years - the same guys were going to do the same things in the same ways. They were going to play slow, they weren't always going to rebound or defend and they were going to play it relatively safe to overcome some athletic deficiencies. Don't expect that blueprint to carry over with Micah Shrewsberry. He'll play more guys, regardless of position, play faster and demand that his guys dig in a little more on the defensive end (though we saw no defensive drills during Tuesday's media viewing window). Like in the past, expect Notre Dame to shoot A LOT of 3s. It's where the game is. It's not about pounding it down low with two bigs and hammering teams. It's wide-open, free flowing. In that regard, they should be fun to watch, even if the wins don't arrive as quickly as some want/expect.

Adam - St. Louis: Tom: Give us your early impressions on the way Shrews is recruiting. He seems a little more active than the previous staff? Any thoughts on current commits?Thomas Noie: Adam: Active and aggressive, especially in the state of Indiana and the Midwest. In getting to know the staff, expect the Midwest to be a heavy emphasis. I was struck by a comment assistant coach Ryan "Ghost" Owens made when I visited with him. He said the staff would be committing recruiting malpractice if they didn't look for players in Indiana and the immediate surrounding states. Notre Dame has only one commitment for 2024 - guard Cole Certa from Bloomington, Illinois. Certa was solid during the summer evaluation period and will play his senior year at IMG Academy in Bradenton, Florida. He's a player. I'd expect a few more to join him as Shrewsberry and his staff figure out who fits the Notre Dame recruit profile.

Jim from Evanston: What has been the biggest positive change Shrewsberry has made to the program so far?Thomas Noie: Jim: It's a relatively small sample size because we've not seen THAT much of practices or been around those guys (still time for that) but I'd say in watching Tuesday it would be Shrewsberry's ability to communicate what he wants done and the way he teaches. He's already rolled up his sleeves and gone to work on the practice floor. The demands are high, but it's what this program needed. He's raised the bar, whether in the weight room or on the practice floor. In the past, it was players who held other players accountable - they kind of coached themselves. Now, though, the accountability starts with the head coach. It's understood what the expectations are from Shrewsberry on down. Different guy, different approach. Refreshing in that regard.

J.J. Post: If no other Portal additions are made and Markus Burton does end up the lone true point guard on the roster - whether he earns the starting designation or not, what are reasonable expectations for his freshman season?Thomas Noie: J.J.: If the season started tonight, Markus Burton is the starting point guard. He's actually the only true point guard on the roster, though there are certainly others who could swing over and handle in case of emergency. I don't think the roster is going past 10 this season. You get the feeling that Shrewsberry and the staff have their guys and their going to move forward with this group the way it is. Reasonable expectations? Be a solid point guard. Burton averaged 30 ppg., as a senior at Penn High School last winter. He won't average half of that next season, and doesn't have to. If he can get to double figures, fine, but it's more important (for now) that he confidently gets this team into their offense, takes care of the ball, defends, make the occasional open shot and maybe above all, plays with a confidence that carries over to other players. Shrewsberry knows Burton will make mistakes. It's part of the process. But stay confident through it, and believe that he belongs.

J.J. Post: Shrewsberry has continually preached playing a system that will fit the players on the roster rather than have any one consistent hallmark, something reflected by his willingness to play his unique 'bootyball' scheme at Penn State. Given the roster as constructed at present, what are some key elements you suspect his 2023 system will possess?Thomas Noie: J.J.: Hard to say, because we haven't seen enough of how the pieces fit. Based on what we did see on Tuesday, this team is going to shoot a lot of 3s. Everybody from Matt Zona to Markus Burton will have the green light to take that shot if it's a good shot. So there's that. Expect this offense to feature a lot of moving and cutting and screening and reading and reacting to what the defense is doing. Not run specific, regimented sets. The bigs are Matt Zona, Kebba Njie and Carey Booth. I don't know that they have a true post-up/back-to-the-basket presence. Njie could eventually be that, but it will be tough to pound it into the post given the size and athleticism that awaits in the Atlantic Coast Conference. It will be intriguing to see how the offense evolves as league play unfolds. It might be a struggle given the lack of size and experience. Shrewesberry will figure it out.

Guest: In the near term, what rising high school players for 2024 recruitment is ND pursuing in addition to its one commitment in Certa.Thomas Noie: There's a core five of Sir Mohammed, CG, 6-6, 200, Charlotte, North Carolina, Jackson McAndrew, PF, 6-8, 190 Wayzata, Minnesota, Garrett Sundra, PF, 6-10, 215, Fairfax, Virginia, Trent Perry, CG, 6-4, 215 Studio City, California and Travis Perry (no relation), PG, 6-2, 170, Eddyville, Kentucky. How many scholarships Notre Dame will eventually have for the 2024 recruiting class (which already includes Cole Certa) remains to be determined. Notre Dame's roster currently carries 10 scholarship players, and all 10 are eligible to return next season. If that happens - and that's a big IF - Notre Dame would have only three spots (two with Certa committed) for the 2024 class.

Matt,: Tom, with the staff finally set Shrews can really lock into recruiting. How many do you see bringing in the 2024 class.Thomas Noie: Matt: Kind of/sort of answered the question above (or below). Notre Dame has 10 scholarship players on the roster for 2023-24 and all 10 have eligibility remaining in some way, shape or form. Seniors Tony Sanders and Matt Zona have the COVID year to go. With Cold Certa committed, Notre Dame would have only two scholarships available. That might change as this season unfolds.

Matt,: how many do you see him bringing in the next 2 classes?Thomas Noie: Matt: That's the $64,000 question that has no answer. Nobody can say because of what the immediate eligibility transfer rule has done to college basketball. Your roster is your roster but it's never really set. Nobody might leave come spring. Two players might leave. Or four. Nobody really knows, which makes it hard to plan for in a recruiting sense. Notre Dame had what, two guys enter the portal since it became the portal before last spring, when five guys bailed. It's impossible to tell.

Banks Asleson: What Impact will Markus Burton have as a freshman? Will he start?Thomas Noie: Banks: As of today, he's the starting (and only true) point guard on the roster. He's going to play and play a lot. Don't expect him to post Indiana Mr. Basketball numbers as a freshman. As long as he can coordinate everything and take care of the ball and defend, it will be a successful season. He'd benefit from playing behind a veteran guard, just so he can learn the game, get stronger and kind of see everything from a patient perspective. That's probably not going to happen. It's going to be right into the fire of the ACC for Burton. Is he ready? There's no choice. He has to be.

Jon: Now that Brey is gone will more players get a chance to play. what's the new coaches take on playing more then six deep!! I liked the energy Matt Zona brought when given the minuscule chances (minutes) in games and then when given more than the 2 minutes at the end of games Sanders, Campbell and he usually got. Zona really showed his long range touch and strength down low the final two or three games.Thomas Noie: Jon: Micah Shrewsberry likely will play more guys this season, but that will be more out of necessity of not having a core four of veterans to lean on, which is what he did at Penn State. FOur Lions all started at least 33 games and played at least 28.2 minutes per game last season, so it wasn't that far off from Notre Dame's penchant for leaning on a veteran group. What was different was how Shrewsberry utilized his bench, where eight players all logged at least 10-plus minutes and 11 played at least eight-plus minutes with eight different players each logging at least four starts. Markus Burton is going to play. A lot. Same for Julian Roper and Kebba Njie. Maybe Matt Zona. Maybe J.R. Koniecnzy. It will look different in many ways; it might look the same in others.

Linas from Orange County, CA: Hey Tom! Happy Summer. Curious about your take on these visits by potential transfers like Paul Mulcahy (can't get anymore Irish than that last name:) and Joe Gerard. Any sense from them why they didn't choose Notre Dame? Is it something to do academics/credits, or the fact that most don't expect an NCAA tournament bid from this young team, or something else? Also, considering Notre Dame's stellar academic reputation why someone like Chris Ledlum from Harvard wouldn't consider the Irish? Thanks for keeping the Irish talk going through the summerThomas Noie: Linas: Usually when you have guys like that who have been around the college basketball block, they're looking for something specific. Like NIL money. Or the chance to win. Mulcahy played in the NCAA tournament at Rutgers, so there's that. Would've been nice to have him (Girard, not so much) but getting a veteran grad transfer at this point was a really hard sell. Notre Dame is not expected to be very successful this season. If you have one more year and you want to win and you want to play in the NCAA tournament, you're probably not going to do it at Notre Dame next season.

JET from Evansville: Who will b our best player?Thomas Noie: JET: How's this for some insight ... I have no idea. None. I didn't see enough of the Irish earlier this week that one or two guys jumped out and said, hey, keep an eye on me. I'm ready. If I had to guess, I'd say Kebba Njie in that he's played a season for Shrewsberry, he knows the system, he looks the part and he's going to get a big chance. Everyone else was just kind of OK. Nothing good. Nothing bad.

Brian from Mishawaka: Coach ... Given your ties to IU-South Bend, can we expect a pre-season/exhibition game with the Titans this year? Coach Cooper has taken his team to the NAIAs for the past several seasons and they've won the CCAC championship a few times as well. Lots of fans on both sides would love to see this match-up!Thomas Noie: Brian: I'm sure Micah Shrewsberry loves the idea, but maybe a year or two down the road. Given how Notre Dame is complete rebuild mode, it's more important in November to play a game against competition that's going to challenge them more than IUSB would. Those kind of exhibition games are good for about a half or a half of a half, and then you get nothing out of them. That said, Notre Dame does plan to play a secret (shhhhh....don't tell anyone) scrimmage against Xavier (somewhere between here and Cincinnati, probably Indy). It would be good to play another secret scrimmage. This Irish team needs seasoning more than area fans need to see a local matchup. Keep that IUSB game on the back burner, though. Good call.

JP, San Diego: Tom, first time long time. There is a ton of reason for optimism around Micah and the program. Namely a lot of strength and conditioning videos/clips on social this summer. We are tired of having our upperclassmen bullied physically in conference play. How archaic was the previous setup (still Rolinski/shared S/C coach with hockey?) and how much of a difference do you expect to see on the court with a dedicated S/C staff now in place?Thomas Noie: JP: You probably can't find five former players who would have anything negative to say about former strength and conditioning coach Tony Rolinski. Players absolutely loved the guy. He was tough but fair and was a sounding board away from the court for so many. Back when they used to run through a year-end banquet (thank God those days are over) every single senior who spoke shouted out T-Ro for helping them get through the tough times. That Rolinski split his time between sports (hoops and hockey) speaks more toward Notre Dame living in the dark ages of strength and conditioning. Hope to soon sit with new strength and conditioning coach Greg Miskinis for a deeper dive into what needs to change from that standpoint. Seeing him at work Tuesday, he's going to be good.

JP, San Diego: Both potentially great players. Who will have a bigger impact on the program when we look back in ten years— Markus Burton or Carey Booth?Thomas Noie: JP: Great question. When it doubt, though, go with the local guy, right? The guy you've seen play in person a ton. The guy you know. The guy whose chip on the shoulder is deep. Burton was doubted at Penn the way he's going to be doubted at Notre Dame. He delivered in high school and has to do it again. Booth could be a future pro given his bloodlines, but I've not seen enough of him to say for certain that he's a can't-miss kid. If both develop and then flourish, Burton might be around Notre Dame more than Booth.

Mark Oliver: Hi Tom, Hope your summer is going well. I like the Micah hire obviously and it seems he'll get the program back on track, but it will be weird following a team this year where they are mostly all transfers and you know much about anybody. I know it's the new normal, but what can you tell me to help get me excited come September so I can sink my teeth into the new season and connect this mixed bags of guys with the Irish program. Thanks.Thomas Noie: Mark: So, you're asking me to put on my carnival barker hat ... step right up ladies and gentlemen, step right up and come and see the Irish men's basketball team, which will feature two locak guys (maybe both in the starting lineup), and a freshmen class that might be better than average in a few years. There's also fan favorite Matt Zona, who will do more than just sit and watch at the end of the bench. And there's Kebba Njie, who knows what elite college basketball is all about. If you're coming out to watch this team this season, you're not coming out to watch them win or chase a possible NCAA tournament bid. You're coming out to say you were on the ground floor when this program gets back to being good.

Dennis Huyvaert: Hi Tom , I cannot wait to see how Marcus Burton performs this year. Do you think he can has as big an impact his first year as Blake Wesley had ?Thomas Noie: Dennis: Whoa.....nothing like raising the bar of expectations my man. That's a big ask/expectation. Wesley led the team in scoring (14.4 ppg.). He played in all 35 games and made 28 starts. he averaged 29.4 minutes per game and was a second team all-Atlantic Coast Conference guy and all-rookie selection. He had an NBA-type of body (scrawny as it was) from the jump. He was one of the few who believed he could be a one-and-done (and then he was). Burton's a different kind of player and will be on a team that's not going to go 15-5 in the ACC and come within two minutes of getting to the Sweet 16. Burton has a chance to be good, but not that good. At least not right away.

Steve Duff: Love the summer hoops talk! What are realistic expectations for this team in your opinion? With nearly all new faces - how do you even project? I’m cautiously optimistic, but there are just so many unknowns. Also who are the difference makers /playmakers on the squad outside of Markus Burton? Thanks for doing this Tom and keep up the great work!Thomas Noie: Steve: Everything about this program continues to be a blank slate. There are too many unknowns and too few knows. Like, really none. If this team can double its league win total and go 6-14, that's a step, right? It's hard to see how the parts fit and who will be the difference-makers. Markus Burton has a chance because he offers something the roster doesn't have. Kebba Njie could be good. Julian Roper is going to play because Micah Shrewsberry loves his toughness. Can Matt Zona carry over what he did in limited minutes in the last game of the season last year? It's going to be intriguing, that's for sure.

Tim from Chicago: Hi Tom, how would you grade the performance of Goodwin, Laz and Wesley in the recent NBA summer league?Thomas Noie: Tim: Incomplete for Dane Goodwin (Sacramento) and Nate Laszewski (Indiana). Not enough minutes to evaluate. They were longshots as it was. That Laszewski didn't make a 3 (0-for-9) kind of sealed his future fate (Europe). As for Blake Wesley, he had a massive opportunity as the starting point guard for San Antonio. He put up some nice numbers (12.8 ppg., 6.0 rpg., 3.0 apg., 29.1 mpg) but there were three red flags - his shooting percentages of 31.0 percent from the field (ugh), 21.4 percent from 3 (ugh) and 63.2 percent from the foul line (ugh). They say it's a make or miss league, and that's so true. If Blake Wesley's not long for the league, there will be no secret as to why it didn't work.

Mike: Hi Tom, slightly holding out hope that JR has a similar breakout year like Abro did coming off his Redshift season. Any thoughts on where he fits this year?Thomas Noie: If my six observations from this week's sneak peek at the program (https://tinyurl.com/msw6nktr) had run seven deep, No. 7 would've been something about J.R. Koniecnzy. Specifically, this is a big prove-it year for him. He barely played as a freshman and sat out last season to preserve a year of eligibility. How has that benefitted him? Did his game get better? Did he get stronger? He has a chance to start this season. How will he chase that? Will he? Micah Shrewsberry said Konieczny still needs to slow down a little bit - not everything can be the same speed. He's also seen him get more confident with his shot - something that wasn't the case when the new coach arrived. Play time for J.R. is over. It's time to deliver, and show (and show early) that those last two years weren't wasted.

Guest: Tom…..can Shrews possibly win 10 games this year and how long will it take for a tournament bid?Thomas Noie: We've seen that anything is possible in college basketball today. Is it likely? This program's probably not winning 10 ACC games. Last year was a disaster of all disasters and Notre Dame still won 11 overall. I'd go with the over on 10, but not that far over.

Tony: Tom, have you seen Tony or Matt workout? I have seen pictures and both seem to be bigger/slimmer, stronger. I hope they both contribute!Thomas Noie: Tony: I'd go with Matt Zona having more of a role than Tony Sanders. It wouldn't be a surprise if Zona started (at least, to start). Sanders might be behind Konieczny and Tae Davis as a wing. It's hard to go that deep on the depth chart. Both will have opportunity to show more and do more than previous seasons, so the chance is there.

Illinois Fool: Who can we expect to play the Point since Micah seems to have missed out on getting a veteran transfer? How much time would you guess Burton will play?Thomas Noie: IF: Right now, the job's Markus Burton's and only Burton's as the only true point guard on the roster. Micah Shrewsberry seemed pretty set as far back as May in terms of moving forward with this group as is, so I wouldn't say he "missed out" on a veteran point guard. I don't know how much he really wanted one. Or saw one that fit his plans.

Mike from Mount Holly: Is my assumption that the offense will struggle more than the defense a correct one? And what should fans expect to see defensively? Does Coach already know what sort of defensive setup this first ND team will be able to hang it's hat on?Thomas Noie: Mike: Defense? What is this concept of which you speak? We saw 30 minutes of work earlier this week, and not one minute of that time was devoted to defense. It was all about offense and movement and cutting and swinging the ball and making shots. What is this team going to be defensively? No idea. I don't know and I don't know that Micah Shrewesberry knows. This group hasn't even played five-on-five yet this summer so to say for sure that this group can do this and this and this well on defense, that's not the case. Not yet. They'll get there, though.

JJ - Ft. Wayne: If you had to field a starting five tomorrow who would they be and who would be your first two off the bench?Thomas Noie: PG - Markus Burton; SG - Julian Roper WF - J.R. Konieczny PF - Kebba Njie, Matt Zona. Top reserves: Carey Booth, Tae Davis. Possible changes? Flip Davis for Koniecnzy and Booth for Zona.

joe from the south side: Tom, About a week ago, Norlander of CBS did a great piece on the hiring of Shrew. In this quote, he talked about Jack S. and the hiring process. "This was to be his 28th (and likely final) head-coaching hire. He began by calling three shoot-for-the-moon candidatess, who all said no." Can you fill in the blanks? Part 2. The article talks about nearing the end of the process. "Notre Dame was effectively down to two candidates by this stage and had an encouraging signal from its No. 2 that it would be a yes if Shrewsberry was a no." DeVries, Langel or a 3rd party?Thomas Noie: Joe: Let's go with Monty Williams, Brad Stevens and Jay Wright for question No. 1 and either Gregg McDermott or Chris Holtmann for question No. 2. Word as that search wound down was that DeVries and Langel weren't really as involved as many figured, for whatever reason. This really was a one-candidate process from the start. It was Shrewsberry from the start, Shrewsberry in the middle and Shrewsberry at the end. It really was that simple.

Ryan mars pa: Tom how has Matt Zona looked at open practice and how does the team look so far in open practice in the Micah Shrewsberry era go IrishThomas Noie: Ryan: Matt Zona has a chance to be a main guy this year. This team has a long, long way to go. They may not get there this year or next, but they'll get there.

Ryan Hoover fan: Tom is this the most off season enthusiasm you have seen for nd hoops in awhile?Thomas Noie: You mean since, let's see .... last summer? The previous year, Notre Dame had set a school record for most league wins (15), came within two minutes of getting to the Sweet 16 for the first time in six seasons, returned three veteran guys and had a talented freshman class that featured a McDonald's All-American on campus. That group - not us dopes in the media - talked as late as October of winning the Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season championship and getting to an NCAA Final Four. There was plenty of enthusiasm for where last season could go, before it all historically fell apart to the point where the winningest coach in program history said, forget this, I'm out. There's enthusiasm, sure, but it's more about what this program can eventually become under Micah Shrewsberry, even though that might not be until four, five years down the basketball road.

Tom from Jersey shore: Tom thanks for the summer basketball chat. Do you know when the full schedule is being released or have you heard any other games besides Marquette, G-Town and South CarolinaThomas Noie: Tom: Get off the chat and get to the shore, my man....come on! I kid....it will be some time before the full schedule is released - it usually doesn't happen until around Labor Day. Notre Dame might be close to releasing its non-league slate soon, and we could hear the home-only and road-only and repeat opponents in the Atlantic Coast Conference will be, but dates won't be finalized for a few more months. As for non-league, Notre Dame is at Marquette and at South Carolina.

Nathan- South Bend: Do you see Tony Sanders playing at all this year? considering other than maybe a little his freshman year, I don't remember him playing much, if at all. we don't really know what he can doThomas Noie: Nathan: Everything - and everybody - is on the playing-time table. They have to be with so few experienced guys who've never gone through the grind of a season. Tony Sanders is right there with J.R. Konieczny and Matt Zona - guys who barely have played, but who now have a chance to hit the reset button and show the staff that they deserve a longer look.

Paul R: I know this team is very young and inexperienced compared to last years group, but is it reasonable to believe they could win more conference games this year?Thomas Noie: Paul: At the very least, Notre Dame should be better than 3-17 in the league. Even if it's an average - or below average - team, it has to be better than 3-7 at home in league play as it was last year. And 0-10 on the road? Speaks to how this team just kind of collectively quit to go winless away from home. Even a bad team can scratch out at least one win somewhere away from home in league play. So yeah, better than 3-17 in the league this season, for sure.

Aidan: How do you see Carey Booth fitting in this year. As he has the highest ceiling on the team but also is very raw coming out of high-school. So does he get thrown in early and see how he plays or is he gonna be someone we see as maybe starting the season playing 10-15 minutes?

Thomas Noie: Aidan: Carey Booth is as intriguing a prospect/player as anyone on the roster. He's like a young deer, kind of wobbly legged trying to walk/run/play all at the same time. He needs reps. He needs weight. He needs experience, but has so much potential. He could be a guy who maybe doesn't start at the start and then by January, you're like, whoa, he's ready for a bigger role. He's just so young. Give him time. He'll make the most of it.

Illinois Fool: What are the chances of Shrew adding another player this summer? If I remember correctly he said that as long as a player was on campus by the fall things could work out.Thomas Noie: IF: I'd say the prospect of that happening is rather slim. Never say never in college basketball when a prospect might just appear one day and everything fits and he's on campus for the start of the fall semester. Listening to Shrewsberry the other day, you get the feeling that he's OK moving forward with this current roster. He's said that he won't make a stop-gap/quick decision on a prospect just to plug a hole. Everything about a possible player has to fit - short-term and long-term. That's a tough ask/find as August nears.

Todd from NC: Based on what you may be hearing, where do we stand in the Jackson McAndrews chase? (We have at least a 25 percent chance at landing him!!!)Thomas Noie: Todd: He's one of the main targets for Notre Dame in the 2024, so there's that. And that he has Notre Dame in his top four means there's mutual interest. But it's recruiting, so even when you think you know, you don't...😄

Illinois Fool: Will the scheduling philosophy change much under the new regime?Thomas Noie: IF: Too early to tell. When I sat with Micah Shrewsberry in early May, he had too many other areas that required his attention that he admitted he hadn't thought much (really, at all) about future scheduling, philosophy, etc. He did open the door to the idea of doing some cool/different/unique scheduling stuff similar to what the Notre Dame women's program is doing in playing South Carolina in Paris. Notre Dame will replace Marquette with Georgetown next season, so he does kind of get keeping some sort of connection with its Big East/private school past. A future home-and-home with Butler and Purdue are possibilities given Shrewsberry's connections to both schools. Notre Dame also will get an annual game with an SEC school, as part of the SEC/ACC Challenge. No more annual Big Ten commitment, and a recruiting emphasis on the Midwest, will open the chance to possibly add a Big Ten school here and there.

Tom, Atlanta - I wish I could be more optimistic, Tom, but this could be ND’s worst season since Digger’s first year. Patience will be required.Thomas Noie: For those too young to remember, that would be 6-20 in 1971-72 under a young Digger Phelps. Patience is an absolute must. Plenty of it. This is going to be a long year in many ways. That's what happens when you return only three players and have to build it back in the manner that Notre Dame requires. Micah Shrewsberry couldn't just mine the transfer portal for a quick fix. That's not this school. Or program. This is going to take time. Give him it.

Mike C: Hey Tom, can you confirm the new S&C guy is strictly for Men's Hoops and he won't be splitting time like Rolinski did?Thomas Noie: Mike: Greg Miskinis is indeed men's basketball only in terms of strength and conditioning. No dual roles. It's all hoops. He was with Micah Shrewsberry last season at Penn State, so he'll know exactly what the head coach wants/needs/expects.

Bobby Singer: Tom let’s say we can and only take 2 more on the 24 class who are the most likely 2 and who are the 2 you would want the most realistically?Thomas Noie: Bobby: I respect the question, but don't know enough about any of the guys to say for sure they're next in line. Who are they as people? As players? What does this team lack? Doesn't lack? Too many unknowns right now, so throwing a dart at the board, let's go with Jackson McAndrew for size and Sir Mohammed for versatility. Might also be good to get a point guard, either in the Class of 2024 or out of the portal.

J.J. Post: It feels like minutes for J.R. Koniecnzy has been the white whale of Notre Dame MBB for the last two seasons. It was impossible to watch his dunks in pregame warmups and not wonder how he couldn't seem to find serious minutes on an Irish team that wasn't exactly firing on all cylinders last year. Is it known what the reason was for him being unable to get on the floor last year - redshirt protection? And is there a sense that on a young, full-rebuild team he could finally step into a sizable role?Thomas Noie: Uhhh.....white whale? In what ways? It didn't matter if he was ready or somewhat ready or nowhere close to being ready (this), there was zero chance that Koniecnzy was going to play as a true freshman with a perimeter that featured Prentiss Hubb, Dane Goodwin, Cormac Ryan and a guy by the name of Blake Wesley. No chance for J.R. It was only slightly better last season, but too few minutes for him to matter, which is why he sat out. Once you decide to sit to redshirt, you have to stay seated to redshirt. No reason to burn an entire year for what, a week or two of meaningful minutes. It was understood on the front end of Koniecnzy's recruitment that this would be a long-term process. Now it's time for him to show it on the back end. There's opportunity. There's a role for him. There's maybe a starting role for him. He has to show that those first two years were spent smartly, that he learned the game, that he got stronger and got better. It's up to him now to deliver. It's there for him.

joe from the south side: Tom, Based on the tea leaves........Trent Perry-No Chance. Los Angeles kid destined for the PAC 12/Big 10 (since SoCal is recruiting him). Only Rex P. and Richie Branning (throwback reference of the day) would make that move. Travis Perry-I had to look him up since I don't believe ND has even offered him. Maybe a backup PG if the other PG falls thru. Jackson McAndrew-ND has a puncher's chance. Let's add Garrett Sundra here too, since they play the same position. Sundra looks to be Plan B. He's the kid Brey would get when the real recruit he wanted went elsewhere. For Shrew, that would be Kon Knueppel-Cole Certa. Lastly, Sir Mohammed. Close to 0%. He backed away from ND once before. If you said NO once, you can easily say it twice. With 10 current and probably not too much turnover (we will see), Shrew is likely looking at 2 or 3 guys. Certa, McAndrew/Sundra and MAYBE MAYBE one wild card who surfaces later.Thomas Noie: My tea leaves (coming from people who know way more than me) are a bit different, particularly when it comes to Mohammed. Get him and Certa and Sundra and McAndrew and call it a class. Let's go.

joe from the south side: Tom, Can you provide insight on how the coaching and support staff has evolved under Shrew? How many now vs. Brey? Is the overall budget for staff significantly better? Is this indicative of Brey being asleep at the switch and Shrew is more plugged in? Has the ND admin. finally realized that to compete in today's free spending, free agent world of college sports, you better pony up or bow out? Your thoughts?Thomas Noie: When it came to his staff/support structure, Mike Brey often liked to tell the story of the night Notre Dame played Ohio State at Purcell Pavilion in December 2020. Brey walked out of the locker room just before tip, looked over at the Buckeye bench and saw that they had something like 15 staff members all in golf shirts. He remembers thinking, now THAT'S a basketball program, where you have enough emphasis/university support to throw enough money at however many assistants you need. In 2022 when Notre Dame played Texas Tech in the NCAA tournament, the Red Raider team picture on its web site featured 47 individuals - coaches, players, support staff, etc. Notre Dame will never be THAT serious about hoops, but the message was clear - it had to do better than three assistant coaches, an ops guy and a video guy. Brey pushed - begged?? - for years to extend the staff to help get his players more help. Notre Dame never budged.

Last year, the Irish men's basketball program had a head coach, an associate head coach, two assistant coaches, a video coordinator and an ops/recruiting coordinator. Six people. This year's men's basketball program has a head coach, an associate head coach, two assistant coaches, an assistant to the head coach, two recruiting staffers and an ops guy. Eight total. Notre Dame finally got serious about its support staff. Kind of a right time, right guy thing for Shrewsberry,

John: Is Knueppel a moon shot? Know there was mention of him visiting in August.Thomas Noie: That would mean Kon Knueppel would have to be the Brad Stevens or Jay Wright of the 2024 recruiting class to make him a moon shot, right? Wouldn't go down that road.

joe from the south side: Tom, I hope you are right and I am wrong. Same thing I tell the missus. 😃Thomas Noie: Can anyone really be right in recruiting?😃

Guest: Who are the next 3 Irish legends to go in the rafters? Chris Thomas, Matt Carroll, Connaughton/Grant combo spot ?Thomas Noie: It will be interesting to see how the Ring of Honor carries on as we move forward. It was totally a Mike Brey thing. He had the final say on what guy went up next and when. Next up? Think John Paxson, Pat Garrity and Chris Thomas. the Pat Connaughton/Jerian Grant (which should've already happened) might not occur until both are done playing.

joe from the south side: Tom, Not now with free agency. The schools basically had total control over the athletes. Not any more. That's part one of the problem for ND. Part 2 is the academic standards. And Part 3 is the one that burns me the most. ND, or Stanford or Vandy finds a kid early. The kid explodes and here comes Duke, Kentucky.......Can't say as I blame the kid but it has to be frustrating as hell for schools to invest so much into a kid and then have the kid do a 180.Thomas Noie: Preach. All true, and all goes back to what one ND hoops hack wrote in NDI back in January about why this will be a really hard job for the new guy moving forward. We've already seen it - there's no quick portal fix and filling out the roster is a tedious process where fit is critical. There are roadblocks and landmines everywhere for this Notre Dame program, and we haven't even touched NIL. That's why when people shout from the shadows about what the previous head coach couldn't do, you give them the side eye and wonder, what color is the sky in your world? Mike Brey could've done better, but he also could've and maybe should've done a whole lot worse. You can bet there already have been a few times when Micah Shrewsberry and his staff have learned how Notre Dame works and what you can and can't do and have thought, man, this is going to be reallllly difficult. Welcome to Notre Dame.

joe from the south side: Tom, I would never say "ND Hoops hack". I would say "The definitive source for all things ND Men's BBL." That said, as plugged in as Shrew is/was to D1 BBL, to the NBA, and to Indiana state BBL, he knew what he was getting into. Which tells me that deep down, he thinks he is the right man for the job. Sounds good to me.Thomas Noie: That said about Micah, I'm sure there still have been a few "Oh, OK..." moments. Especially with the beat guy he's got to deal with every day for six months come October...😄

Joe, Cape May: From your job perspective, how do you go about gaining rapport with an entirely new staff after working with Brey for so many years and most of his assistants being familiar faces?Thomas Noie: Joe: Just put in the work. I've sat with Micah Shrewsberry and each of his three assistants so far this summer. Get to know them a little. Don't make it all question and answer stuff. Turn off the recorder and just talk with them as people. Let them know who I am, what my job is and no matter what happens - good or bad - I'll be there. Even after a tough game or tough analysis, I'll always be there the next day. Accountability matters. Next up, I'd like to know the strength coach and those behind the scenes a little better. Media and those we cover aren't on the same team in any way shape or form, but we're all kind of on this crazy roller-coaster ride of college basketball together. Brey got that, maybe better than anyone. Shrewsberry's very similar.

Patrick, NYC: Hi Tom! So grateful for this summer chat and the season can't come soon enough. Sounds like a lot of unknowns. To that end, for pure fun speculation, what would be your top 3 pleasant potential surprises for this team next year? (Maybe seeing Zona being a force would be one, I was surprised to see you having him start with Booth on the bench)Thomas Noie: Patrick: In no particular order (OK, some order): Markus Burton hits the ground running and is a problem for other teams to deal with as the starting point guard; this team is a team with no real standout guy but a bunch of guys who are going to get after it and play with a determination that we didn't really see last season to the point where we can see where all of this eventually can go; Matt Zona and Kebba Njie can hold their own against some of the frontline talent they're going to see this season in the ACC. A fourth would be seeing a young/inexperienced guy suddenly blossom/blow up (looking at you Carey Booth and/or J.R. Konieczny. 😄

Guest: Are Anthony Solomon and Antoni Wyche actively looking for coaching gigs?Thomas Noie: No. There's no immediate need for either to work this season.😃

Jim Tal, Valley Center CA.: Given the sorry state of the program that he inherited, it's hard to imagine anyone doing a better job of filling up the roster, reenergizing recruiting and generally stabilizing things than what Micah S. has done. Frankly, I think he's exceeded all possible expectations up to this point. Would you agree, Tom?Thomas Noie: Jim: Absolutely. This was a near-impossible situation - a depleted roster, no returning veterans, no direction, no leadership. The past four months probably have felt more like four years for Shrewsberry, who's been going 100 since he was hired. It's been a long road with a longer one to go. At least there's some stability. Some direction. Some life. This season won't show it through wins, but the payoff will come. Some day.

Justin, Ft. Wayne: I know you had a chance to see the players this week. With the new s&c coach and the videos i’ve seen them post, it looks like the players are looking like actual touch physical basketball players. Any takeaways you had from their physical appearance while watching them?Thomas Noie: Justin: Honestly, no because our viewing window was so small that there wasn't enough time to really look at a guy and think about how his body has changed. There was too much to see, particularly with how Micah Shrewsberry runs a workout. It's easy to say everything's going to be different with a new strength and conditioning coach and guys are going to be bigger, but that doesn't mean better. The physicality aspect, like with everything else Notre Dame men's basketball, is going to be a process. It's going to take time. This team will still have strength/size issues moving forward. It just will.

Illinois Fool: What kind of player should we expect the Shrewsbury kid to be?Thomas Noie: IF: Hate to send you to the principal's office, IF, but, man, let's at least get the last name right. SHREWSBERRY....Give him time to develop. He's been around too much basketball and too high a level to not have at least some of it rub off on him. Hate to keep circling back to the small window we had the other day, but it's hard to really say what he and Logan Imes can be. Need to see a larger sample size. Like five-on-five.

Bill: Thanks Tom for the extensive updates— I’m surprised Shrews is so focused on mid west especially with so mush competition from the big ten — why not look more recruiting at north east - New York- Jersey - Washington — lots of talent capable of meeting ND academics - thanksThomas Noie: Bill: The Midwest will be INCLUDED in the recruiting footprint, something that wasn't always the case in seasons past. Ryan Owens' background in AAU is in the Midwest. The guy knows everybody, so it would be foolish to dismiss kids in Illinois and Ohio and Michigan and deeper into Indiana because it's Big Ten country. Given that it takes a special kind of kid to go to Notre Dame, they'll look anywhere. By no means are they going to limit themselves to this or that region.

JDub, Ft. Wayne: Does the fact that Micah worked under Brad Stevens and Matt Painter for so long, and achieved a lot of success with them, does that impress you at all and give you a better feeling that he will succeed as a head coach, or is it really more the person that succeeds and not who they really learned from in this case?Thomas Noie: JuDub: Great that he worked for Painter and Stevens, but what does he know? How does he coach? How does he run a program? How does he handle success? Adversity? It's not like Painter or Stevens are these elite of elite coaches/basketball savants who've enjoyed endless success. They're good. Shrewsberry can draw on those experiences and add a wrinkle or two of his own. Matt Doherty played for Dean Smith and worked for Roy Williams, but he struggled as a head coach at the elite level. It doesn't automatically happen.

Chris. Fairfax, Va: Tom, Do you think more fans will attend games this year ? So frustrating to see the empty seats. Thanks. Chris.Thomas Noie: Chris: You're going to get me in trouble with the fan base now, aren't you? Good. Let's go. Time for the fan base (and you too student body) to put up or shut up. Heard for years about how they didn't like this and they didn't like that and if only this or that was different would they be more interested in the program. Well, guess what, EVERYTHING about the program is new and different. Time for them to get excited and get behind basketball. No more excuses now, right? Yep, that's the grumpy old beat writer being the grumpy, old beat writer. But we heard for years how they tired of the old regime and if only they were gone would everything change. They're gone. Will they change? We'll see.

Todd Leahy, Charlotte: Hopefully you know where Charlotte is and I don't need to type NC. Is it too early to tell what the relationship will be like between Shrewsberry and Pete Bevacqua? Is the new AD going to be too focused on renewing the NBC deal?Thomas Noie: Todd: Charlotte, Arizona??? LOL. Yeah, way too early. Pete Bevacqua was at the Notre Dame hoops workout earlier this week, but probably wasn't about to digest it too deep with everything else on his plate. That he's an ND guy has to work in the program's favor. Shrewsberry gets it. Bevacqua does as well. Still, it's weird that the guy who hired you is out the door less than a year later, which shouldn't be all that much of a surprise. Swarbrick wasn't expected to still be in the job by 2025.

Chris. Fairfax, Va: I wonder if JR is still the best dunker? They have some athleticism on the team.Thomas Noie: Think he'd trade that title for best player. Time to build out the resume to include more than just being good in the pre-practice layup line.

search_result.title: Kentucky Derby 2025 live updates: Sovereignty wins 151st race
search_result.text:
The Kentucky Derby is finally here, and few things are more iconic than the annual Run for the Roses.

Held at the Churchill Downs Racetrack in Louisville, the Kentucky Derby, also known as "The Greatest Two Minutes in Sports," is a big (big!) race. The 2025 Kentucky Derby purse will once again be $5 million, matching the record-breaking payout from Derby 150 in 2024. With $3.1 million going to the winner and sizable payouts for the top five finishers, the Kentucky Derby remains the richest race in the Triple Crown series — cementing its place as the most coveted prize in Thoroughbred racing, according to the Kentucky Derby website.

In addition to the main event, there are endless things to do and see at the Kentucky Derby from watching (and betting!) the races, to the food, drinks, celebrity sightings, and more.

The Courier Journal has a team covering every aspect of the 151st Kentucky Derby, from the fashion and the food, to the celebrities, the racing, and more, so follow along for live updates whether you're at the track or not. And be sure to download our 2025 Kentucky Derby betting guide!

Happy Derby, y'all!

Final finishing order for the 151st Kentucky Derby

Sovereignty wins Kentucky Derby, with Journalism close behind

Sovereignty won the 151st running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.

Journalism was second and Baeza came in third.

—Josh Wood

How many people came to the 2025 Kentucky Derby?

The official attendance for Kentucky Derby 151 was around 147,400, according to Churchill Downs officials. Last year, Derby Day drew in around 156,700.

The record Derby attendance remains in 2015 that drew in around 170,500.

— Hannah Pinski

Kentucky Derby 2025 needs: Ponchos and cocktails

Louisville native Blair Bell is enjoying one of her highlights of the year with a visit to Churchill Downs for the 151st Kentucky Derby.

“This is my favorite week out of the entire year. You’ve got the energy, the people, anything goes,” she said. “It’s just infectious.”

The born and raised Louisvillian said she’s extremely proud of the city – especially around Derby Week.

“I love the fashion. I love that everyone has a smile on their face,” Bell said. “It’s the energy from the people and I’m so proud of our city this time of year.”

Bell, who is attending with her husband, said she’s betting on Tiztastic for the Run for the Roses and that rain or shine, Derby Day is always a fun experience. She encourages those to embrace the weather with some good rain gear and a drink.

“A great poncho and also a cocktail and just knowing that it’s going to be okay,” she said. “You got to lean in and rain or shine, you’re just going to have a good time.”

— Marina Johnson

LMPD: I-65 crash cleared, roadway reopened

Less than an hour before running of the 151st Kentucky Derby, the Louisville Metro Police Department said a multi-vehicle crash on I-65 S had in Louisville had been cleared.

“Update: As of 6:05pm on 5-3-25 our Traffic Unit & First Division have REOPNED the roadway,” LMPD wrote on X.

A crash involving a semi truck and at least three other vehicles occurred on I-65 S at the Kennedy Bridge hours earlier, shutting down I-65 S and diverting traffic to I-64.

—Josh Wood

Simone Biles, other Olympians, pick Chunk of Gold

Olympic gymnast Simone Biles — who will do the “Riders Up” call before the 151st running of the Kentucky Derby tonight — said Chunk of Gold is her pick in the race.

She made the comments during an interview with NBC.

While Chunk of Gold is not the favorite with 26-1 odds, there’s something about his name that might be attractive to Olympians.

In videos broadcast by NBC before Biles gave her pick, several other Olympians said they were rooting for the gray/roan colt.

“As an Olympian, I had to pick Chunk of Gold. It was the obvious option,” said freestyle skier Alex Hall.

Bobsledder Elana Meyers Taylor shared that sentiment saying: “Chunk of Gold, because that’s what I plan on winning in the 2026 Olympics.”
